Algebra with Sympy v0.12.0
built with pdoc

algebra_with_sympy.algebraic_equation

Algebraic Equations with SymPy

These tools define relations that all high school and college students would recognize as mathematical equations. They consist of a left hand side (lhs) and a right hand side (rhs) connected by a relation operator such as "=". At present the "=" relation operator is the only option. The relation operator may not be set.

This class should not be confused with the Boolean class Equality (abbreviated Eq) which specifies that the equality of two objects is True.

This tool applies operations to both sides of the equation simultaneously, just as students are taught to do when attempting to isolate (solve for) a variable. Thus the statement Equation/b yields a new equation Equation.lhs/b = Equation.rhs/b

The intent is to allow using the mathematical tools in SymPy to rearrange equations and perform algebra in a stepwise fashion. In this way more people can successfully perform algebraic rearrangements without stumbling over missed details such as a negative sign. This mimics the capabilities available in SageMath and Maxima.

   1"""
   2Algebraic Equations with SymPy
   3==============================
   4
   5These tools define relations that all high school and college students would
   6recognize as mathematical equations. They consist of a left hand side (lhs)
   7and a right hand side (rhs) connected by a relation operator such as "=". At
   8present the "=" relation operator is the only option. The relation operator may
   9not be set.
  10
  11This class should not be confused with the Boolean class ``Equality``
  12(abbreviated ``Eq``) which specifies that the equality of two objects is
  13``True``.
  14
  15This tool applies operations to both sides of the equation simultaneously, just
  16as students are taught to do when attempting to isolate (solve for) a
  17variable. Thus the statement ``Equation/b`` yields a new equation
  18``Equation.lhs/b = Equation.rhs/b``
  19
  20The intent is to allow using the mathematical tools in SymPy to rearrange
  21equations and perform algebra in a stepwise fashion. In this way more people
  22can successfully perform algebraic rearrangements without stumbling over
  23missed details such as a negative sign. This mimics the capabilities available
  24in [SageMath](https://www.sagemath.org/) and
  25[Maxima](http://maxima.sourceforge.net/).
  26"""
  27import sys
  28
  29import sympy
  30from sympy.core.add import _unevaluated_Add
  31from sympy.core.expr import Expr
  32from sympy.core.basic import Basic
  33from sympy.core.evalf import EvalfMixin
  34from sympy.core.sympify import _sympify
  35from algebra_with_sympy.preparser import integers_as_exact
  36import functools
  37from sympy import *
  38
  39class algwsym_config():
  40
  41    def __init__(self):
  42        """
  43        This is a class to hold parameters that control behavior of
  44        the algebra_with_sympy package.
  45
  46        Settings
  47        ========
  48        Printing
  49        --------
  50        In interactive environments the default output of an equation is a
  51        human readable string with the two sides connected by an equals
  52        sign or a typeset equation with the two sides connected by an equals sign.
  53        `print(Eqn)` or `str(Eqn)` will return this human readable text version of
  54        the equation as well. This is consistent with python standards, but not
  55        sympy, where `str()` is supposed to return something that can be
  56        copy-pasted into code. If the equation has a declared name as in `eq1 =
  57        Eqn(a,b/c)` the name will be displayed to the right of the equation in
  58        parentheses (eg. `a = b/c    (eq1)`). Use `print(repr(Eqn))` instead of
  59        `print(Eqn)` or `repr(Eqn)` instead of `str(Eqn)` to get a code
  60        compatible version of the equation.
  61
  62        You can adjust this behvior using some flags that impact output:
  63        * `algwsym_config.output.show_code` default is `False`.
  64        * `algwsym_config.output.human_text` default is `True`.
  65        * `algwsym_config.output.label` default is `True`.
  66
  67        In interactive environments you can get both types of output by setting
  68        the `algwsym_config.output.show_code` flag. If this flag is true
  69        calls to `latex` and `str` will also print an additional line "code
  70        version: `repr(Eqn)`". Thus in Jupyter you will get a line of typeset
  71        mathematics output preceded by the code version that can be copy-pasted.
  72        Default is `False`.
  73
  74        A second flag `algwsym_config.output.human_text` is useful in
  75        text-based interactive environments such as command line python or
  76        ipython. If this flag is true `repr` will return `str`. Thus the human
  77        readable text will be printed as the output of a line that is an
  78        expression containing an equation.
  79        Default is `True`.
  80
  81        Setting both of these flags to true in a command line or ipython
  82        environment will show both the code version and the human readable text.
  83        These flags impact the behavior of the `print(Eqn)` statement.
  84
  85        The third flag `algwsym_config.output.label` has a default value of
  86        `True`. Setting this to `False` suppresses the labeling of an equation
  87        with its python name off to the right of the equation.
  88        """
  89        pass
  90
  91    class output():
  92
  93        def __init__(self):
  94            """This holds settings that impact output.
  95            """
  96            pass
  97
  98        @property
  99        def show_code(self):
 100            """
 101            If `True` code versions of the equation expression will be
 102            output in interactive environments. Default = `False`.
 103            """
 104            return self.show_code
 105
 106        @property
 107        def human_text(self):
 108            """
 109            If `True` the human readable equation expression will be
 110            output in text interactive environments. Default = `False`.
 111            """
 112            return self.human_text
 113
 114        @property
 115        def solve_to_list(self):
 116            """
 117            If `True` the results of a call to `solve(...)` will return a
 118            Python `list` rather than a Sympy `FiniteSet`. This recovers
 119            behavior for versions before 0.11.0.
 120
 121            Note: setting this `True` means that expressions within the
 122            returned solutions will not be pretty-printed in Jupyter and
 123            IPython.
 124            """
 125            return self.solve_to_list
 126
 127    class numerics():
 128
 129        def __init__(self):
 130            """This class holds settings for how numerical computation and
 131            inputs are handled.
 132            """
 133            pass
 134
 135        def integers_as_exact(self):
 136            """**This is a flag for informational purposes and interface
 137            consistency. Changing the value will not change the behavior.**
 138
 139            To change the behavior call:
 140            * `unset_integers_as_exact()` to turn this feature off.
 141            * `set_integers_as_exact()` to turn this feature on (on by
 142            default).
 143
 144            If set to `True` (the default) and if running in an
 145            IPython/Jupyter environment any number input without a decimal
 146            will be interpreted as a sympy integer. Thus, fractions and
 147            related expressions will not evalute to floating point numbers,
 148            but be maintained as exact expressions (e.g. 2/3 -> 2/3 not the
 149            float 0.6666...).
 150            """
 151            return self.integers_as_exact
 152
 153def __latex_override__(expr, *arg):
 154    from IPython import get_ipython
 155    show_code = False
 156    if get_ipython():
 157        algwsym_config = get_ipython().user_ns.get("algwsym_config", False)
 158    else:
 159        algwsym_config = globals()['algwsym_config']
 160    if algwsym_config:
 161        show_code = algwsym_config.output.show_code
 162    if show_code:
 163        print("Code version: " + repr(expr))
 164    return '$'+latex(expr) + '$'
 165
 166def __command_line_printing__(expr, *arg):
 167    # print('Entering __command_line_printing__')
 168    human_text = True
 169    show_code = False
 170    if algwsym_config:
 171        human_text = algwsym_config.output.human_text
 172        show_code = algwsym_config.output.show_code
 173    tempstr = ''
 174    if show_code:
 175        tempstr += "Code version: " + repr(expr) + '\n'
 176    if not human_text:
 177        return print(tempstr + repr(expr))
 178    else:
 179        return print(tempstr + str(expr))
 180
 181# Now we inject the formatting override(s)
 182from IPython import get_ipython
 183ip = get_ipython()
 184formatter = None
 185if ip:
 186    # In an environment that can display typeset latex
 187    formatter = ip.display_formatter
 188    old = formatter.formatters['text/latex'].for_type(Basic,
 189                                                      __latex_override__)
 190    # print("For type Basic overriding latex formatter = " + str(old))
 191
 192    # For the terminal based IPython
 193    if "text/latex" not in formatter.active_types:
 194        old = formatter.formatters['text/plain'].for_type(tuple,
 195                                                    __command_line_printing__)
 196        # print("For type tuple overriding plain text formatter = " + str(old))
 197        for k in sympy.__all__:
 198            if k in globals() and not "Printer" in k:
 199                if isinstance(globals()[k], type):
 200                    old = formatter.formatters['text/plain'].\
 201                        for_type(globals()[k], __command_line_printing__)
 202                    # print("For type "+str(k)+
 203                    # " overriding plain text formatter = " + str(old))
 204else:
 205    # command line
 206    # print("Overriding command line printing of python.")
 207    sys.displayhook = __command_line_printing__
 208
 209# Numerics controls
 210def set_integers_as_exact():
 211    """This operation uses `sympy.interactive.session.int_to_Integer`, which
 212    causes any number input without a decimal to be interpreted as a sympy
 213    integer, to pre-parse input cells. It also sets the flag
 214    `algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = True` This is the default
 215    mode of algebra_with_sympy. To turn this off call
 216    `unset_integers_as_exact()`.
 217    """
 218    from IPython import get_ipython
 219    if get_ipython():
 220        get_ipython().input_transformers_post.append(integers_as_exact)
 221        algwsym_config = get_ipython().user_ns.get("algwsym_config", False)
 222        if algwsym_config:
 223            algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = True
 224        else:
 225            raise ValueError("The algwsym_config object does not exist.")
 226    return
 227
 228def unset_integers_as_exact():
 229    """This operation disables forcing of numbers input without
 230    decimals being interpreted as sympy integers. Numbers input without a
 231    decimal may be interpreted as floating point if they are part of an
 232    expression that undergoes python evaluation (e.g. 2/3 -> 0.6666...). It
 233    also sets the flag `algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = False`.
 234    Call `set_integers_as_exact()` to avoid this conversion of rational
 235    fractions and related expressions to floating point. Algebra_with_sympy
 236    starts with `set_integers_as_exact()` enabled (
 237    `algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = True`).
 238    """
 239    from IPython import get_ipython
 240    if get_ipython():
 241        pre = get_ipython().input_transformers_post
 242        # The below looks excessively complicated, but more reliably finds the
 243        # transformer to remove across varying IPython environments.
 244        for k in pre:
 245            if "integers_as_exact" in k.__name__:
 246                pre.remove(k)
 247        algwsym_config = get_ipython().user_ns.get("algwsym_config", False)
 248        if algwsym_config:
 249            algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = False
 250        else:
 251            raise ValueError("The algwsym_config object does not exist.")
 252
 253    return
 254
 255class Equation(Basic, EvalfMixin):
 256    """
 257    This class defines an equation with a left-hand-side (tlhs) and a right-
 258    hand-side (rhs) connected by the "=" operator (e.g. `p*V = n*R*T`).
 259
 260    Explanation
 261    ===========
 262    This class defines relations that all high school and college students
 263    would recognize as mathematical equations. At present only the "=" relation
 264    operator is recognized.
 265
 266    This class is intended to allow using the mathematical tools in SymPy to
 267    rearrange equations and perform algebra in a stepwise fashion. In this
 268    way more people can successfully perform algebraic rearrangements without
 269    stumbling over missed details such as a negative sign.
 270
 271    Create an equation with the call ``Equation(lhs,rhs)``, where ``lhs`` and
 272    ``rhs`` are any valid Sympy expression. ``Eqn(...)`` is a synonym for
 273    ``Equation(...)``.
 274
 275    Parameters
 276    ==========
 277    lhs: sympy expression, ``class Expr``.
 278    rhs: sympy expression, ``class Expr``.
 279    kwargs:
 280
 281    Examples
 282    ========
 283    NOTE: All the examples below are in vanilla python. You can get human
 284    readable eqautions "lhs = rhs" in vanilla python by adjusting the settings
 285    in `algwsym_config` (see it's documentation). Output is human readable by
 286    default in IPython and Jupyter environments.
 287    >>> from algebra_with_sympy import *
 288    >>> a, b, c, x = var('a b c x')
 289    >>> Equation(a,b/c)
 290    Equation(a, b/c)
 291    >>> t=Eqn(a,b/c)
 292    >>> t
 293    Equation(a, b/c)
 294    >>> t*c
 295    Equation(a*c, b)
 296    >>> c*t
 297    Equation(a*c, b)
 298    >>> exp(t)
 299    Equation(exp(a), exp(b/c))
 300    >>> exp(log(t))
 301    Equation(a, b/c)
 302
 303    Simplification and Expansion
 304    >>> f = Eqn(x**2 - 1, c)
 305    >>> f
 306    Equation(x**2 - 1, c)
 307    >>> f/(x+1)
 308    Equation((x**2 - 1)/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
 309    >>> (f/(x+1)).simplify()
 310    Equation(x - 1, c/(x + 1))
 311    >>> simplify(f/(x+1))
 312    Equation(x - 1, c/(x + 1))
 313    >>> (f/(x+1)).expand()
 314    Equation(x**2/(x + 1) - 1/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
 315    >>> expand(f/(x+1))
 316    Equation(x**2/(x + 1) - 1/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
 317    >>> factor(f)
 318    Equation((x - 1)*(x + 1), c)
 319    >>> f.factor()
 320    Equation((x - 1)*(x + 1), c)
 321    >>> f2 = f+a*x**2+b*x +c
 322    >>> f2
 323    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c + x**2 - 1, a*x**2 + b*x + 2*c)
 324    >>> collect(f2,x)
 325    Equation(b*x + c + x**2*(a + 1) - 1, a*x**2 + b*x + 2*c)
 326
 327    Apply operation to only one side
 328    >>> poly = Eqn(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
 329    >>> poly.applyrhs(factor,x)
 330    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, x*(c + x**2*(a + b)))
 331    >>> poly.applylhs(factor)
 332    Equation(x*(a*x + b + c*x), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
 333    >>> poly.applylhs(collect,x)
 334    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
 335
 336    ``.apply...`` also works with user defined python functions
 337    >>> def addsquare(eqn):
 338    ...     return eqn+eqn**2
 339    ...
 340    >>> t.apply(addsquare)
 341    Equation(a**2 + a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
 342    >>> t.applyrhs(addsquare)
 343    Equation(a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
 344    >>> t.apply(addsquare, side = 'rhs')
 345    Equation(a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
 346    >>> t.applylhs(addsquare)
 347    Equation(a**2 + a, b/c)
 348    >>> addsquare(t)
 349    Equation(a**2 + a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
 350
 351    Inaddition to ``.apply...`` there is also the less general ``.do``,
 352    ``.dolhs``, ``.dorhs``, which only works for operations defined on the
 353    ``Expr`` class (e.g.``.collect(), .factor(), .expand()``, etc...).
 354    >>> poly.dolhs.collect(x)
 355    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
 356    >>> poly.dorhs.collect(x)
 357    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, c*x + x**3*(a + b))
 358    >>> poly.do.collect(x)
 359    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), c*x + x**3*(a + b))
 360    >>> poly.dorhs.factor()
 361    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, x*(a*x**2 + b*x**2 + c))
 362
 363    ``poly.do.exp()`` or other sympy math functions will raise an error.
 364
 365    Rearranging an equation (simple example made complicated as illustration)
 366    >>> p, V, n, R, T = var('p V n R T')
 367    >>> eq1=Eqn(p*V,n*R*T)
 368    >>> eq1
 369    Equation(V*p, R*T*n)
 370    >>> eq2 =eq1/V
 371    >>> eq2
 372    Equation(p, R*T*n/V)
 373    >>> eq3 = eq2/R/T
 374    >>> eq3
 375    Equation(p/(R*T), n/V)
 376    >>> eq4 = eq3*R/p
 377    >>> eq4
 378    Equation(1/T, R*n/(V*p))
 379    >>> 1/eq4
 380    Equation(T, V*p/(R*n))
 381    >>> eq5 = 1/eq4 - T
 382    >>> eq5
 383    Equation(0, -T + V*p/(R*n))
 384
 385    Substitution (#'s and units)
 386    >>> L, atm, mol, K = var('L atm mol K', positive=True, real=True) # units
 387    >>> eq2.subs({R:0.08206*L*atm/mol/K,T:273*K,n:1.00*mol,V:24.0*L})
 388    Equation(p, 0.9334325*atm)
 389    >>> eq2.subs({R:0.08206*L*atm/mol/K,T:273*K,n:1.00*mol,V:24.0*L}).evalf(4)
 390    Equation(p, 0.9334*atm)
 391
 392    Substituting an equation into another equation:
 393    >>> P, P1, P2, A1, A2, E1, E2 = symbols("P, P1, P2, A1, A2, E1, E2")
 394    >>> eq1 = Eqn(P, P1 + P2)
 395    >>> eq2 = Eqn(P1 / (A1 * E1), P2 / (A2 * E2))
 396    >>> P1_val = (eq1 - P2).swap
 397    >>> P1_val
 398    Equation(P1, P - P2)
 399    >>> eq2 = eq2.subs(P1_val)
 400    >>> eq2
 401    Equation((P - P2)/(A1*E1), P2/(A2*E2))
 402    >>> P2_val = solve(eq2.subs(P1_val), P2).args[0]
 403    >>> P2_val
 404    Equation(P2, A2*E2*P/(A1*E1 + A2*E2))
 405
 406    Combining equations (Math with equations: lhs with lhs and rhs with rhs)
 407    >>> q = Eqn(a*c, b/c**2)
 408    >>> q
 409    Equation(a*c, b/c**2)
 410    >>> t
 411    Equation(a, b/c)
 412    >>> q+t
 413    Equation(a*c + a, b/c + b/c**2)
 414    >>> q/t
 415    Equation(c, 1/c)
 416    >>> t**q
 417    Equation(a**(a*c), (b/c)**(b/c**2))
 418
 419    Utility operations
 420    >>> t.reversed
 421    Equation(b/c, a)
 422    >>> t.swap
 423    Equation(b/c, a)
 424    >>> t.lhs
 425    a
 426    >>> t.rhs
 427    b/c
 428    >>> t.as_Boolean()
 429    Eq(a, b/c)
 430
 431    `.check()` convenience method for `.as_Boolean().simplify()`
 432    >>> from sympy import I, pi
 433    >>> Equation(pi*(I+2), pi*I+2*pi).check()
 434    True
 435    >>> Eqn(a,a+1).check()
 436    False
 437
 438    Differentiation
 439    Differentiation is applied to both sides if the wrt variable appears on
 440    both sides.
 441    >>> q=Eqn(a*c, b/c**2)
 442    >>> q
 443    Equation(a*c, b/c**2)
 444    >>> diff(q,b)
 445    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b), c**(-2))
 446    >>> diff(q,c)
 447    Equation(a, -2*b/c**3)
 448    >>> diff(log(q),b)
 449    Equation(Derivative(log(a*c), b), 1/b)
 450    >>> diff(q,c,2)
 451    Equation(Derivative(a, c), 6*b/c**4)
 452
 453    If you specify multiple differentiation all at once the assumption
 454    is order of differentiation matters and the lhs will not be
 455    evaluated.
 456    >>> diff(q,c,b)
 457    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b, c), -2/c**3)
 458
 459    To overcome this specify the order of operations.
 460    >>> diff(diff(q,c),b)
 461    Equation(Derivative(a, b), -2/c**3)
 462
 463    But the reverse order returns an unevaulated lhs (a may depend on b).
 464    >>> diff(diff(q,b),c)
 465    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b, c), -2/c**3)
 466
 467    Integration can only be performed on one side at a time.
 468    >>> q=Eqn(a*c,b/c)
 469    >>> integrate(q,b,side='rhs')
 470    b**2/(2*c)
 471    >>> integrate(q,b,side='lhs')
 472    a*b*c
 473
 474    Make a pretty statement of integration from an equation
 475    >>> Eqn(Integral(q.lhs,b),integrate(q,b,side='rhs'))
 476    Equation(Integral(a*c, b), b**2/(2*c))
 477
 478    Integration of each side with respect to different variables
 479    >>> q.dorhs.integrate(b).dolhs.integrate(a)
 480    Equation(a**2*c/2, b**2/(2*c))
 481
 482    Automatic solutions using sympy solvers. THIS IS EXPERIMENTAL. Please
 483    report issues at https://github.com/gutow/Algebra_with_Sympy/issues.
 484    >>> tosolv = Eqn(a - b, c/a)
 485    >>> solve(tosolv,a)
 486    FiniteSet(Equation(a, b/2 - sqrt(b**2 + 4*c)/2), Equation(a, b/2 + sqrt(b**2 + 4*c)/2))
 487    >>> solve(tosolv, b)
 488    FiniteSet(Equation(b, (a**2 - c)/a))
 489    >>> solve(tosolv, c)
 490    FiniteSet(Equation(c, a**2 - a*b))
 491    """
 492
 493    def __new__(cls, lhs, rhs, **kwargs):
 494        lhs = _sympify(lhs)
 495        rhs = _sympify(rhs)
 496        if not isinstance(lhs, Expr) or not isinstance(rhs, Expr):
 497            raise TypeError('lhs and rhs must be valid sympy expressions.')
 498        return super().__new__(cls, lhs, rhs)
 499
 500    def _get_eqn_name(self):
 501        """
 502        Tries to find the python string name that refers to the equation. In
 503        IPython environments (IPython, Jupyter, etc...) looks in the user_ns.
 504        If not in an IPython environment looks in __main__.
 505        :return: string value if found or empty string.
 506        """
 507        human_text = algwsym_config.output.human_text
 508        algwsym_config.output.human_text=False
 509        import __main__ as shell
 510        for k in dir(shell):
 511            item = getattr(shell,k)
 512            if isinstance(item,Equation):
 513                if item.__repr__()==self.__repr__() and not \
 514                        k.startswith('_'):
 515                    algwsym_config.output.human_text=human_text
 516                    return k
 517        algwsym_config.output.human_text = human_text
 518        return ''
 519
 520    @property
 521    def lhs(self):
 522        """
 523        Returns the lhs of the equation.
 524        """
 525        return self.args[0]
 526
 527    @property
 528    def rhs(self):
 529        """
 530        Returns the rhs of the equation.
 531        """
 532        return self.args[1]
 533
 534    def as_Boolean(self):
 535        """
 536        Converts the equation to an Equality.
 537        """
 538        return Equality(self.lhs, self.rhs)
 539
 540    def check(self, **kwargs):
 541        """
 542        Forces simplification and casts as `Equality` to check validity.
 543        Parameters
 544        ----------
 545        kwargs any appropriate for `Equality`.
 546
 547        Returns
 548        -------
 549        True, False or an unevaluated `Equality` if truth cannot be determined.
 550        """
 551        return Equality(self.lhs, self.rhs, **kwargs).simplify()
 552
 553    @property
 554    def reversed(self):
 555        """
 556        Swaps the lhs and the rhs.
 557        """
 558        return Equation(self.rhs, self.lhs)
 559
 560    @property
 561    def swap(self):
 562        """
 563        Synonym for `.reversed`
 564        """
 565        return self.reversed
 566
 567    def _applytoexpr(self, expr, func, *args, **kwargs):
 568        # Applies a function to an expression checking whether there
 569        # is a specialized version associated with the particular type of
 570        # expression. Errors will be raised if the function cannot be
 571        # applied to an expression.
 572        funcname = getattr(func, '__name__', None)
 573        if funcname is not None:
 574            localfunc = getattr(expr, funcname, None)
 575            if localfunc is not None:
 576                return localfunc(*args, **kwargs)
 577        return func(expr, *args, **kwargs)
 578
 579    def apply(self, func, *args, side='both', **kwargs):
 580        """
 581        Apply an operation/function/method to the equation returning the
 582        resulting equation.
 583
 584        Parameters
 585        ==========
 586
 587        func: object
 588            object to apply usually a function
 589
 590        args: as necessary for the function
 591
 592        side: 'both', 'lhs', 'rhs', optional
 593            Specifies which side of the equation the operation will be applied
 594            to. Default is 'both'.
 595
 596        kwargs: as necessary for the function
 597         """
 598        lhs = self.lhs
 599        rhs = self.rhs
 600        if side in ('both', 'lhs'):
 601            lhs = self._applytoexpr(self.lhs, func, *args, **kwargs)
 602        if side in ('both', 'rhs'):
 603            rhs = self._applytoexpr(self.rhs, func, *args, **kwargs)
 604        return Equation(lhs, rhs)
 605
 606    def applylhs(self, func, *args, **kwargs):
 607        """
 608        If lhs side of the equation has a defined subfunction (attribute) of
 609        name ``func``, that will be applied instead of the global function.
 610        The operation is applied to only the lhs.
 611        """
 612        return self.apply(func, *args, **kwargs, side='lhs')
 613
 614    def applyrhs(self, func, *args, **kwargs):
 615        """
 616        If rhs side of the equation has a defined subfunction (attribute) of
 617        name ``func``, that will be applied instead of the global function.
 618        The operation is applied to only the rhs.
 619        """
 620        return self.apply(func, *args, **kwargs, side='rhs')
 621
 622    class _sides:
 623        """
 624        Helper class for the `.do.`, `.dolhs.`, `.dorhs.` syntax for applying
 625        submethods of expressions.
 626        """
 627
 628        def __init__(self, eqn, side='both'):
 629            self.eqn = eqn
 630            self.side = side
 631
 632        def __getattr__(self, name):
 633            func = None
 634            if self.side in ('rhs', 'both'):
 635                func = getattr(self.eqn.rhs, name, None)
 636            else:
 637                func = getattr(self.eqn.lhs, name, None)
 638            if func is None:
 639                raise AttributeError('Expressions in the equation have no '
 640                                     'attribute `' + str(
 641                    name) + '`. Try `.apply('
 642                                     + str(name) + ', *args)` or '
 643                                                   'pass the equation as a parameter to `'
 644                                     + str(name) + '()`.')
 645            return functools.partial(self.eqn.apply, func, side=self.side)
 646
 647    @property
 648    def do(self):
 649        return self._sides(self, side='both')
 650
 651    @property
 652    def dolhs(self):
 653        return self._sides(self, side='lhs')
 654
 655    @property
 656    def dorhs(self):
 657        return self._sides(self, side='rhs')
 658    
 659    def _eval_rewrite(self, rule, args, **kwargs):
 660        """Return Equation(L, R) as Equation(L - R, 0) or as L - R.
 661
 662        Parameters
 663        ==========
 664
 665        evaluate : bool, optional
 666            Control the evaluation of the result. If `evaluate=None` then
 667            terms in L and R will not cancel but they will be listed in
 668            canonical order; otherwise non-canonical args will be returned.
 669            Default to True.
 670        
 671        eqn : bool, optional
 672            Control the returned type. If `eqn=True`, then Equation(L - R, 0)
 673            is returned. Otherwise, the L - R symbolic expression is returned.
 674            Default to True.
 675
 676        Examples
 677        ========
 678        >>> from sympy import Add
 679        >>> from sympy.abc import b, x
 680        >>> from algebra_with_sympy import Equation
 681        >>> eq = Equation(x + b, x - b)
 682        >>> eq.rewrite(Add)
 683        Equation(2*b, 0)
 684        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, evaluate=None).lhs.args
 685        (b, b, x, -x)
 686        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, evaluate=False).lhs.args
 687        (b, x, b, -x)
 688        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, eqn=False)
 689        2*b
 690        >>> eq.rewrite(Add, eqn=False, evaluate=False).args
 691        (b, x, b, -x)
 692        """
 693        if rule == Add:
 694            # NOTE: the code about `evaluate` is very similar to
 695            # sympy.core.relational.Equality._eval_rewrite_as_Add
 696            eqn = kwargs.pop("eqn", True)
 697            evaluate = kwargs.get('evaluate', True)
 698            L, R = args
 699            if evaluate:
 700                # allow cancellation of args
 701                expr = L - R
 702            else:
 703                args = Add.make_args(L) + Add.make_args(-R)
 704                if evaluate is None:
 705                    # no cancellation, but canonical
 706                    expr = _unevaluated_Add(*args)
 707                else:
 708                    # no cancellation, not canonical
 709                    expr = Add._from_args(args)
 710            if eqn:
 711                return self.func(expr, 0)
 712            return expr
 713
 714    def subs(self, *args, **kwargs):
 715        """Substitutes old for new in an equation after sympifying args.
 716    
 717        `args` is either:
 718
 719        * one or more arguments of type `Equation(old, new)`.
 720        * two arguments, e.g. foo.subs(old, new)
 721        * one iterable argument, e.g. foo.subs(iterable). The iterable may be:
 722
 723            - an iterable container with (old, new) pairs. In this case the
 724              replacements are processed in the order given with successive
 725              patterns possibly affecting replacements already made.
 726            - a dict or set whose key/value items correspond to old/new pairs.
 727              In this case the old/new pairs will be sorted by op count and in
 728              case of a tie, by number of args and the default_sort_key. The
 729              resulting sorted list is then processed as an iterable container
 730              (see previous).
 731        
 732        If the keyword ``simultaneous`` is True, the subexpressions will not be
 733        evaluated until all the substitutions have been made.
 734
 735        Please, read ``help(Expr.subs)`` for more examples.
 736
 737        Examples
 738        ========
 739
 740        >>> from sympy.abc import a, b, c, x
 741        >>> from algebra_with_sympy import Equation
 742        >>> eq = Equation(x + a, b * c)
 743
 744        Substitute a single value:
 745
 746        >>> eq.subs(b, 4)
 747        Equation(a + x, 4*c)
 748
 749        Substitute a multiple values:
 750
 751        >>> eq.subs([(a, 2), (b, 4)])
 752        Equation(x + 2, 4*c)
 753        >>> eq.subs({a: 2, b: 4})
 754        Equation(x + 2, 4*c)
 755
 756        Substitute an equation into another equation:
 757
 758        >>> eq2 = Equation(x + a, 4)
 759        >>> eq.subs(eq2)
 760        Equation(4, b*c)
 761
 762        Substitute multiple equations into another equation:
 763
 764        >>> eq1 = Equation(x + a + b + c, x * a * b * c)
 765        >>> eq2 = Equation(x + a, 4)
 766        >>> eq3 = Equation(b, 5)
 767        >>> eq1.subs(eq2, eq3)
 768        Equation(c + 9, 5*a*c*x)
 769
 770        """
 771        new_args = args
 772        if all(isinstance(a, self.func) for a in args):
 773            new_args = [{a.args[0]: a.args[1] for a in args}]
 774        elif (len(args) == 1) and all(isinstance(a, self.func) for a in
 775                                      args[0]):
 776            raise TypeError("You passed into `subs` a list of elements of "
 777                "type `Equation`, but this is not supported. Please, consider "
 778                "unpacking the list with `.subs(*eq_list)` or select your "
 779                "equations from the list and use `.subs(eq_list[0], eq_list["
 780                "2], ...)`.")
 781        elif any(isinstance(a, self.func) for a in args):
 782            raise ValueError("`args` contains one or more Equation and some "
 783                "other data type. This mode of operation is not supported. "
 784                "Please, read `subs` documentation to understand how to "
 785                "use it.")
 786        return super().subs(*new_args, **kwargs)
 787
 788    #####
 789    # Overrides of binary math operations
 790    #####
 791
 792    @classmethod
 793    def _binary_op(cls, a, b, opfunc_ab):
 794        if isinstance(a, Equation) and not isinstance(b, Equation):
 795            return Equation(opfunc_ab(a.lhs, b), opfunc_ab(a.rhs, b))
 796        elif isinstance(b, Equation) and not isinstance(a, Equation):
 797            return Equation(opfunc_ab(a, b.lhs), opfunc_ab(a, b.rhs))
 798        elif isinstance(a, Equation) and isinstance(b, Equation):
 799            return Equation(opfunc_ab(a.lhs, b.lhs), opfunc_ab(a.rhs, b.rhs))
 800        else:
 801            return NotImplemented
 802
 803    def __add__(self, other):
 804        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a + b)
 805
 806    def __radd__(self, other):
 807        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a + b)
 808
 809    def __mul__(self, other):
 810        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a * b)
 811
 812    def __rmul__(self, other):
 813        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a * b)
 814
 815    def __sub__(self, other):
 816        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a - b)
 817
 818    def __rsub__(self, other):
 819        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a - b)
 820
 821    def __truediv__(self, other):
 822        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a / b)
 823
 824    def __rtruediv__(self, other):
 825        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a / b)
 826
 827    def __mod__(self, other):
 828        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a % b)
 829
 830    def __rmod__(self, other):
 831        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a % b)
 832
 833    def __pow__(self, other):
 834        return self._binary_op(self, other, lambda a, b: a ** b)
 835
 836    def __rpow__(self, other):
 837        return self._binary_op(other, self, lambda a, b: a ** b)
 838
 839    def _eval_power(self, other):
 840        return self.__pow__(other)
 841
 842    #####
 843    # Operation helper functions
 844    #####
 845    def expand(self, *args, **kwargs):
 846        return Equation(self.lhs.expand(*args, **kwargs), self.rhs.expand(
 847            *args, **kwargs))
 848
 849    def simplify(self, *args, **kwargs):
 850        return self._eval_simplify(*args, **kwargs)
 851
 852    def _eval_simplify(self, *args, **kwargs):
 853        return Equation(self.lhs.simplify(*args, **kwargs), self.rhs.simplify(
 854            *args, **kwargs))
 855
 856    def _eval_factor(self, *args, **kwargs):
 857        # TODO: cancel out factors common to both sides.
 858        return Equation(self.lhs.factor(*args, **kwargs), self.rhs.factor(
 859            *args, **kwargs))
 860
 861    def factor(self, *args, **kwargs):
 862        return self._eval_factor(*args, **kwargs)
 863
 864    def _eval_collect(self, *args, **kwargs):
 865        from sympy.simplify.radsimp import collect
 866        return Equation(collect(self.lhs, *args, **kwargs),
 867                        collect(self.rhs, *args, **kwargs))
 868
 869    def collect(self, *args, **kwargs):
 870        return self._eval_collect(*args, **kwargs)
 871
 872    def evalf(self, *args, **kwargs):
 873        return Equation(self.lhs.evalf(*args, **kwargs),
 874                        self.rhs.evalf(*args, **kwargs))
 875
 876    n = evalf
 877
 878    def _eval_derivative(self, *args, **kwargs):
 879        # TODO Find why diff and Derivative do not appear to pass through
 880        #  kwargs to this. Since we cannot set evaluation of lhs manually
 881        #  try to be intelligent about when to do it.
 882        from sympy.core.function import Derivative
 883        eval_lhs = False
 884        if not (isinstance(self.lhs, Derivative)):
 885            for sym in args:
 886                if sym in self.lhs.free_symbols and not (
 887                        _sympify(sym).is_number):
 888                    eval_lhs = True
 889        return Equation(self.lhs.diff(*args, **kwargs, evaluate=eval_lhs),
 890                        self.rhs.diff(*args, **kwargs))
 891
 892    def _eval_Integral(self, *args, **kwargs):
 893        side = kwargs.pop('side', None)  # Could not seem to pass values for
 894        # `evaluate` through to here.
 895        if side is None:
 896            raise ValueError('You must specify `side="lhs"` or `side="rhs"` '
 897                             'when integrating an Equation')
 898        else:
 899            try:
 900                return (getattr(self, side).integrate(*args, **kwargs))
 901            except AttributeError:
 902                raise AttributeError('`side` must equal "lhs" or "rhs".')
 903
 904    #####
 905    # Output helper functions
 906    #####
 907    def __repr__(self):
 908        repstr = 'Equation(%s, %s)' %(self.lhs.__repr__(), self.rhs.__repr__())
 909        # if algwsym_config.output.human_text:
 910        #     return self.__str__()
 911        return repstr
 912
 913    def _latex(self, printer):
 914        tempstr = ''
 915        """
 916        if algwsym_config.output.show_code and not \
 917            algwsym_config.output.human_text:
 918            print('code version: '+ self.__repr__())
 919        """
 920        tempstr += printer._print(self.lhs)
 921        tempstr += '='
 922        tempstr += printer._print(self.rhs)
 923        namestr = self._get_eqn_name()
 924        if namestr !='' and algwsym_config.output.label:
 925            tempstr += '\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,'
 926            tempstr += '(\\text{'+namestr+'})'
 927        return tempstr
 928
 929    def __str__(self):
 930        tempstr = ''
 931        # if algwsym_config.output.show_code:
 932        #     human_text = algwsym_config.output.human_text
 933        #     algwsym_config.output.human_text=False
 934        #     tempstr += '\ncode version: '+self.__repr__() +'\n'
 935        #     algwsym_config.output.human_text=human_text
 936        tempstr += str(self.lhs) + ' = ' + str(self.rhs)
 937        namestr = self._get_eqn_name()
 938        if namestr != '' and algwsym_config.output.label:
 939            tempstr += '          (' + namestr + ')'
 940        return tempstr
 941
 942
 943Eqn = Equation
 944if ip and "text/latex" not in formatter.active_types:
 945    old = formatter.formatters['text/plain'].for_type(Eqn,
 946                                                __command_line_printing__)
 947    # print("For type Equation overriding plain text formatter = " + str(old))
 948
 949def solve(f, *symbols, **flags):
 950    """
 951    Override of sympy `solve()`.
 952
 953    If passed an expression and variable(s) to solve for it behaves
 954    almost the same as normal solve with `dict = True`, except that solutions
 955    are wrapped in a FiniteSet() to guarantee that the output will be pretty
 956    printed in Jupyter like environments.
 957
 958    If passed an equation or equations it returns solutions as a
 959    `FiniteSet()` of solutions, where each solution is represented by an
 960    equation or set of equations.
 961
 962    To get a Python `list` of solutions (pre-0.11.0 behavior) rather than a
 963    `FiniteSet` issue the command `algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list = True`.
 964    This also prevents pretty-printing in IPython and Jupyter.
 965
 966    Examples
 967    --------
 968    >>> a, b, c, x, y = symbols('a b c x y', real = True)
 969    >>> import sys
 970    >>> sys.displayhook = __command_line_printing__ # set by default on normal initialization.
 971    >>> eq1 = Eqn(abs(2*x+y),3)
 972    >>> eq2 = Eqn(abs(x + 2*y),3)
 973    >>> B = solve((eq1,eq2))
 974
 975    Default human readable output on command line
 976    >>> B
 977    {{x = -3, y = 3}, {x = -1, y = -1}, {x = 1, y = 1}, {x = 3, y = -3}}
 978
 979    To get raw output turn off by setting
 980    >>> algwsym_config.output.human_text=False
 981    >>> B
 982    FiniteSet(FiniteSet(Equation(x, -3), Equation(y, 3)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, -1), Equation(y, -1)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, 1), Equation(y, 1)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, 3), Equation(y, -3)))
 983
 984    Pre-0.11.0 behavior where a python list of solutions is returned
 985    >>> algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list = True
 986    >>> solve((eq1,eq2))
 987    [[Equation(x, -3), Equation(y, 3)], [Equation(x, -1), Equation(y, -1)], [Equation(x, 1), Equation(y, 1)], [Equation(x, 3), Equation(y, -3)]]
 988    >>> algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list = False # reset to default
 989
 990    `algwsym_config.output.human_text = True` with
 991    `algwsym_config.output.how_code=True` shows both.
 992    In Jupyter-like environments `show_code=True` yields the Raw output and
 993    a typeset version. If `show_code=False` (the default) only the
 994    typeset version is shown in Jupyter.
 995    >>> algwsym_config.output.show_code=True
 996    >>> algwsym_config.output.human_text=True
 997    >>> B
 998    Code version: FiniteSet(FiniteSet(Equation(x, -3), Equation(y, 3)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, -1), Equation(y, -1)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, 1), Equation(y, 1)), FiniteSet(Equation(x, 3), Equation(y, -3)))
 999    {{x = -3, y = 3}, {x = -1, y = -1}, {x = 1, y = 1}, {x = 3, y = -3}}
1000    """
1001    from sympy.solvers.solvers import solve
1002    from sympy.sets.sets import FiniteSet
1003    from IPython.display import display
1004    newf =[]
1005    solns = []
1006    displaysolns = []
1007    contains_eqn = False
1008    if hasattr(f,'__iter__'):
1009        for k in f:
1010            if isinstance(k, Equation):
1011                newf.append(k.lhs-k.rhs)
1012                contains_eqn = True
1013            else:
1014                newf.append(k)
1015    else:
1016        if isinstance(f, Equation):
1017            newf.append(f.lhs - f.rhs)
1018            contains_eqn = True
1019        else:
1020            newf.append(f)
1021    flags['dict'] = True
1022    result = solve(newf, *symbols, **flags)
1023    if contains_eqn:
1024        if len(result[0]) == 1:
1025            for k in result:
1026                for key in k.keys():
1027                    val = k[key]
1028                    tempeqn = Eqn(key, val)
1029                    solns.append(tempeqn)
1030        else:
1031            for k in result:
1032                solnset = []
1033                for key in k.keys():
1034                    val = k[key]
1035                    tempeqn = Eqn(key, val)
1036                    solnset.append(tempeqn)
1037                if not algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list:
1038                    solnset = FiniteSet(*solnset)
1039                solns.append(solnset)
1040    else:
1041        solns = result
1042    if algwsym_config.output.solve_to_list:
1043        return list(solns)
1044    else:
1045        return FiniteSet(*solns)
1046
1047def solveset(f, symbols, domain=sympy.Complexes):
1048    """
1049    Very experimental override of sympy solveset, which we hope will replace
1050    solve. Much is not working. It is not clear how to input a system of
1051    equations unless you directly select `linsolve`, etc...
1052    """
1053    from sympy.solvers import solveset as solve
1054    from IPython.display import display
1055    newf = []
1056    solns = []
1057    displaysolns = []
1058    contains_eqn = False
1059    if hasattr(f, '__iter__'):
1060        for k in f:
1061            if isinstance(k, Equation):
1062                newf.append(k.lhs - k.rhs)
1063                contains_eqn = True
1064            else:
1065                newf.append(k)
1066    else:
1067        if isinstance(f, Equation):
1068            newf.append(f.lhs - f.rhs)
1069            contains_eqn = True
1070        else:
1071            newf.append(f)
1072    result = solve(*newf, symbols, domain=domain)
1073    # if contains_eqn:
1074    #     if len(result[0]) == 1:
1075    #         for k in result:
1076    #             for key in k.keys():
1077    #                 val = k[key]
1078    #                 tempeqn = Eqn(key, val)
1079    #                 solns.append(tempeqn)
1080    #         display(*solns)
1081    #     else:
1082    #         for k in result:
1083    #             solnset = []
1084    #             displayset = []
1085    #             for key in k.keys():
1086    #                 val = k[key]
1087    #                 tempeqn = Eqn(key, val)
1088    #                 solnset.append(tempeqn)
1089    #                 if algwsym_config.output.show_solve_output:
1090    #                     displayset.append(tempeqn)
1091    #             if algwsym_config.output.show_solve_output:
1092    #                 displayset.append('-----')
1093    #             solns.append(solnset)
1094    #             if algwsym_config.output.show_solve_output:
1095    #                 for k in displayset:
1096    #                     displaysolns.append(k)
1097    #         if algwsym_config.output.show_solve_output:
1098    #             display(*displaysolns)
1099    # else:
1100    solns = result
1101    return solns
1102
1103def sqrt(arg, evaluate = None):
1104    """
1105    Override of sympy convenience function `sqrt`. Simply divides equations
1106    into two sides if `arg` is an instance of `Equation`. This avoids an
1107    issue with the way sympy is delaying specialized applications of _Pow_ on
1108    objects that are not basic sympy expressions.
1109    """
1110    from sympy.functions.elementary.miscellaneous import sqrt as symsqrt
1111    if isinstance(arg, Equation):
1112        return Equation(symsqrt(arg.lhs, evaluate), symsqrt(arg.rhs, evaluate))
1113    else:
1114        return symsqrt(arg,evaluate)
1115
1116# Pick up the docstring for sqrt from sympy
1117from sympy.functions.elementary.miscellaneous import sqrt as symsqrt
1118sqrt.__doc__+=symsqrt.__doc__
1119del symsqrt
1120
1121def root(arg, n, k = 0, evaluate = None):
1122    """
1123    Override of sympy convenience function `root`. Simply divides equations
1124    into two sides if `arg`  or `n` is an instance of `Equation`. This
1125    avoids an issue with the way sympy is delaying specialized applications
1126    of _Pow_ on objects that are not basic sympy expressions.
1127    """
1128    from sympy.functions.elementary.miscellaneous import root as symroot
1129    if isinstance(arg, Equation):
1130        return Equation(symroot(arg.lhs, n, k, evaluate),
1131                        symroot(arg.rhs, n, k, evaluate))
1132    if isinstance(n, Equation):
1133        return Equation(symroot(arg, n.lhs, k, evaluate),
1134                        symroot(arg, n.rhs, k, evaluate))
1135    else:
1136        return symroot(arg, n, k, evaluate)
1137
1138# pick up the docstring for root from sympy
1139from sympy.functions.elementary.miscellaneous import root as symroot
1140root.__doc__+=symroot.__doc__
1141del symroot
1142
1143def Heaviside(arg, **kwargs):
1144    """
1145    Overide of the Heaviside function as implemented in Sympy. Get a recursion
1146    error if use the normal class extension of a function to do this.
1147
1148    """
1149    from sympy.functions.special.delta_functions import Heaviside as symHeav
1150    if isinstance(arg, Equation):
1151        return Equation(symHeav((arg.lhs), **kwargs),symHeav((arg.rhs),
1152                                                             **kwargs))
1153    else:
1154        return symHeav(arg, **kwargs)
1155# Pick up the docstring for Heaviside from Sympy.
1156from sympy.functions.special.delta_functions import Heaviside as symHeav
1157Heaviside.__doc__ += symHeav.__doc__
1158del symHeav
1159
1160def collect(expr, syms, func=None, evaluate=None, exact=False,
1161            distribute_order_term=True):
1162    """
1163    Override of sympy `collect()`.
1164    """
1165    from sympy.simplify.radsimp import collect
1166    _eval_collect = getattr(expr, '_eval_collect', None)
1167    if _eval_collect is not None:
1168        return _eval_collect(syms, func, evaluate,
1169                             exact, distribute_order_term)
1170    else:
1171        return collect(expr, syms, func, evaluate, exact,
1172                       distribute_order_term)
1173
1174class Equality(Equality):
1175    """
1176    Extension of Equality class to include the ability to convert it to an
1177    Equation.
1178    """
1179    def to_Equation(self):
1180        """
1181        Return: recasts the Equality as an Equation.
1182        """
1183        return Equation(self.lhs,self.rhs)
1184
1185    def to_Eqn(self):
1186        """
1187        Synonym for to_Equation.
1188        Return: recasts the Equality as an Equation.
1189        """
1190        return self.to_Equation()
1191
1192Eq = Equality
1193
1194def __FiniteSet__repr__override__(self):
1195    """Override of the `FiniteSet.__repr__(self)` to overcome sympy's
1196    inconsistent wrapping of Finite Sets which prevents reliable use of
1197    copy and paste of the code representation.
1198    """
1199    insidestr = ""
1200    for k in self.args:
1201        insidestr += k.__repr__() +', '
1202    insidestr = insidestr[:-2]
1203    reprstr = "FiniteSet("+ insidestr + ")"
1204    return reprstr
1205
1206sympy.sets.FiniteSet.__repr__ = __FiniteSet__repr__override__
1207
1208def __FiniteSet__str__override__(self):
1209    """Override of the `FiniteSet.__str__(self)` to overcome sympy's
1210    inconsistent wrapping of Finite Sets which prevents reliable use of
1211    copy and paste of the code representation.
1212    """
1213    insidestr = ""
1214    for k in self.args:
1215        insidestr += str(k) + ', '
1216    insidestr = insidestr[:-2]
1217    strrep = "{"+ insidestr + "}"
1218    return strrep
1219
1220sympy.sets.FiniteSet.__str__ = __FiniteSet__str__override__
1221
1222#####
1223# Extension of the Function class. For incorporation into SymPy this should
1224# become part of the class
1225#####
1226class EqnFunction(Function):
1227    """
1228    Extension of the sympy Function class to understand equations. Each
1229    sympy function impacted by this extension is listed in the documentation
1230    that follows.
1231    """
1232    def __new__(cls, *args, **kwargs):
1233        n = len(args)
1234        eqnloc = None
1235        neqns = 0
1236        newargs = []
1237        for k in args:
1238            newargs.append(k)
1239        if (n > 0):
1240            for i in range(n):
1241                if isinstance(args[i], Equation):
1242                    neqns += 1
1243                    eqnloc = i
1244            if neqns > 1:
1245                raise NotImplementedError('Function calls with more than one '
1246                                          'Equation as a parameter are not '
1247                                          'supported. You may be able to get '
1248                                          'your desired outcome using .applyrhs'
1249                                          ' and .applylhs.')
1250            if neqns == 1:
1251                newargs[eqnloc] = args[eqnloc].lhs
1252                lhs = super().__new__(cls, *newargs, **kwargs)
1253                newargs[eqnloc] = args[eqnloc].rhs
1254                rhs = super().__new__(cls, *newargs, **kwargs)
1255                return Equation(lhs,rhs)
1256        return super().__new__(cls, *args, **kwargs)
1257
1258def str_to_extend_sympy_func(func:str):
1259    """
1260    Generates the string command to execute for a sympy function to
1261    gain the properties of the extended EqnFunction class.
1262    """
1263    execstr = 'class ' + str(func) + '(' + str(
1264        func) + ',EqnFunction):\n    ' \
1265                'pass\n'
1266    return execstr
1267
1268# TODO: Below will not be needed when incorporated into SymPy.
1269# This is hacky, but I have not been able to come up with another way
1270# of extending the functions programmatically, if this is separate package
1271# from sympy that extends it after loading sympy.
1272#  Functions listed in `skip` are not applicable to equations or cannot be
1273#  extended because of `mro` error or `metaclass conflict`. This reflects
1274#  that some of these are not members of the Sympy Function class.
1275
1276# Overridden elsewhere
1277_extended_ = ('sqrt', 'root', 'Heaviside')
1278
1279# Either not applicable to equations or have not yet figured out a way
1280# to systematically apply to an equation.
1281# TODO examine these more carefully (top priority: real_root, cbrt, Ynm_c).
1282_not_applicable_to_equations_ = ('Min', 'Max', 'Id', 'real_root', 'cbrt',
1283        'unbranched_argument', 'polarify', 'unpolarify',
1284        'piecewise_fold', 'E1', 'Eijk', 'bspline_basis',
1285        'bspline_basis_set', 'interpolating_spline', 'jn_zeros',
1286        'jacobi_normalized', 'Ynm_c', 'piecewise_exclusive', 'Piecewise',
1287        'motzkin', 'hyper','meijerg', 'chebyshevu_root', 'chebyshevt_root',
1288        'betainc_regularized')
1289_skip_ = _extended_ + _not_applicable_to_equations_
1290
1291for func in functions.__all__:
1292
1293    if func not in _skip_:
1294        try:
1295            exec(str_to_extend_sympy_func(func), globals(), locals())
1296        except TypeError:
1297            from warnings import warn
1298            warn('SymPy function/operation ' + str(func) + ' may not work ' \
1299                'properly with Equations. If you use it with Equations, ' \
1300                'validate its behavior. We are working to address this ' \
1301                'issue.')
1302
1303# Redirect python abs() to Abs()
1304abs = Abs
class algwsym_config: 
 40class algwsym_config():
 41
 42    def __init__(self):
 43        """
 44        This is a class to hold parameters that control behavior of
 45        the algebra_with_sympy package.
 46
 47        Settings
 48        ========
 49        Printing
 50        --------
 51        In interactive environments the default output of an equation is a
 52        human readable string with the two sides connected by an equals
 53        sign or a typeset equation with the two sides connected by an equals sign.
 54        `print(Eqn)` or `str(Eqn)` will return this human readable text version of
 55        the equation as well. This is consistent with python standards, but not
 56        sympy, where `str()` is supposed to return something that can be
 57        copy-pasted into code. If the equation has a declared name as in `eq1 =
 58        Eqn(a,b/c)` the name will be displayed to the right of the equation in
 59        parentheses (eg. `a = b/c    (eq1)`). Use `print(repr(Eqn))` instead of
 60        `print(Eqn)` or `repr(Eqn)` instead of `str(Eqn)` to get a code
 61        compatible version of the equation.
 62
 63        You can adjust this behvior using some flags that impact output:
 64        * `algwsym_config.output.show_code` default is `False`.
 65        * `algwsym_config.output.human_text` default is `True`.
 66        * `algwsym_config.output.label` default is `True`.
 67
 68        In interactive environments you can get both types of output by setting
 69        the `algwsym_config.output.show_code` flag. If this flag is true
 70        calls to `latex` and `str` will also print an additional line "code
 71        version: `repr(Eqn)`". Thus in Jupyter you will get a line of typeset
 72        mathematics output preceded by the code version that can be copy-pasted.
 73        Default is `False`.
 74
 75        A second flag `algwsym_config.output.human_text` is useful in
 76        text-based interactive environments such as command line python or
 77        ipython. If this flag is true `repr` will return `str`. Thus the human
 78        readable text will be printed as the output of a line that is an
 79        expression containing an equation.
 80        Default is `True`.
 81
 82        Setting both of these flags to true in a command line or ipython
 83        environment will show both the code version and the human readable text.
 84        These flags impact the behavior of the `print(Eqn)` statement.
 85
 86        The third flag `algwsym_config.output.label` has a default value of
 87        `True`. Setting this to `False` suppresses the labeling of an equation
 88        with its python name off to the right of the equation.
 89        """
 90        pass
 91
 92    class output():
 93
 94        def __init__(self):
 95            """This holds settings that impact output.
 96            """
 97            pass
 98
 99        @property
100        def show_code(self):
101            """
102            If `True` code versions of the equation expression will be
103            output in interactive environments. Default = `False`.
104            """
105            return self.show_code
106
107        @property
108        def human_text(self):
109            """
110            If `True` the human readable equation expression will be
111            output in text interactive environments. Default = `False`.
112            """
113            return self.human_text
114
115        @property
116        def solve_to_list(self):
117            """
118            If `True` the results of a call to `solve(...)` will return a
119            Python `list` rather than a Sympy `FiniteSet`. This recovers
120            behavior for versions before 0.11.0.
121
122            Note: setting this `True` means that expressions within the
123            returned solutions will not be pretty-printed in Jupyter and
124            IPython.
125            """
126            return self.solve_to_list
127
128    class numerics():
129
130        def __init__(self):
131            """This class holds settings for how numerical computation and
132            inputs are handled.
133            """
134            pass
135
136        def integers_as_exact(self):
137            """**This is a flag for informational purposes and interface
138            consistency. Changing the value will not change the behavior.**
139
140            To change the behavior call:
141            * `unset_integers_as_exact()` to turn this feature off.
142            * `set_integers_as_exact()` to turn this feature on (on by
143            default).
144
145            If set to `True` (the default) and if running in an
146            IPython/Jupyter environment any number input without a decimal
147            will be interpreted as a sympy integer. Thus, fractions and
148            related expressions will not evalute to floating point numbers,
149            but be maintained as exact expressions (e.g. 2/3 -> 2/3 not the
150            float 0.6666...).
151            """
152            return self.integers_as_exact
algwsym_config() 
42    def __init__(self):
43        """
44        This is a class to hold parameters that control behavior of
45        the algebra_with_sympy package.
46
47        Settings
48        ========
49        Printing
50        --------
51        In interactive environments the default output of an equation is a
52        human readable string with the two sides connected by an equals
53        sign or a typeset equation with the two sides connected by an equals sign.
54        `print(Eqn)` or `str(Eqn)` will return this human readable text version of
55        the equation as well. This is consistent with python standards, but not
56        sympy, where `str()` is supposed to return something that can be
57        copy-pasted into code. If the equation has a declared name as in `eq1 =
58        Eqn(a,b/c)` the name will be displayed to the right of the equation in
59        parentheses (eg. `a = b/c    (eq1)`). Use `print(repr(Eqn))` instead of
60        `print(Eqn)` or `repr(Eqn)` instead of `str(Eqn)` to get a code
61        compatible version of the equation.
62
63        You can adjust this behvior using some flags that impact output:
64        * `algwsym_config.output.show_code` default is `False`.
65        * `algwsym_config.output.human_text` default is `True`.
66        * `algwsym_config.output.label` default is `True`.
67
68        In interactive environments you can get both types of output by setting
69        the `algwsym_config.output.show_code` flag. If this flag is true
70        calls to `latex` and `str` will also print an additional line "code
71        version: `repr(Eqn)`". Thus in Jupyter you will get a line of typeset
72        mathematics output preceded by the code version that can be copy-pasted.
73        Default is `False`.
74
75        A second flag `algwsym_config.output.human_text` is useful in
76        text-based interactive environments such as command line python or
77        ipython. If this flag is true `repr` will return `str`. Thus the human
78        readable text will be printed as the output of a line that is an
79        expression containing an equation.
80        Default is `True`.
81
82        Setting both of these flags to true in a command line or ipython
83        environment will show both the code version and the human readable text.
84        These flags impact the behavior of the `print(Eqn)` statement.
85
86        The third flag `algwsym_config.output.label` has a default value of
87        `True`. Setting this to `False` suppresses the labeling of an equation
88        with its python name off to the right of the equation.
89        """
90        pass

This is a class to hold parameters that control behavior of the algebra_with_sympy package.

Settings

Printing

In interactive environments the default output of an equation is a human readable string with the two sides connected by an equals sign or a typeset equation with the two sides connected by an equals sign. print(Eqn) or str(Eqn) will return this human readable text version of the equation as well. This is consistent with python standards, but not sympy, where str() is supposed to return something that can be copy-pasted into code. If the equation has a declared name as in eq1 = Eqn(a,b/c) the name will be displayed to the right of the equation in parentheses (eg. a = b/c (eq1)). Use print(repr(Eqn)) instead of print(Eqn) or repr(Eqn) instead of str(Eqn) to get a code compatible version of the equation.

You can adjust this behvior using some flags that impact output:

  • algwsym_config.output.show_code default is False.
  • algwsym_config.output.human_text default is True.
  • algwsym_config.output.label default is True.

In interactive environments you can get both types of output by setting the algwsym_config.output.show_code flag. If this flag is true calls to latex and str will also print an additional line "code version: repr(Eqn)". Thus in Jupyter you will get a line of typeset mathematics output preceded by the code version that can be copy-pasted. Default is False.

A second flag algwsym_config.output.human_text is useful in text-based interactive environments such as command line python or ipython. If this flag is true repr will return str. Thus the human readable text will be printed as the output of a line that is an expression containing an equation. Default is True.

Setting both of these flags to true in a command line or ipython environment will show both the code version and the human readable text. These flags impact the behavior of the print(Eqn) statement.

The third flag algwsym_config.output.label has a default value of True. Setting this to False suppresses the labeling of an equation with its python name off to the right of the equation.

class algwsym_config.output: 
 92    class output():
 93
 94        def __init__(self):
 95            """This holds settings that impact output.
 96            """
 97            pass
 98
 99        @property
100        def show_code(self):
101            """
102            If `True` code versions of the equation expression will be
103            output in interactive environments. Default = `False`.
104            """
105            return self.show_code
106
107        @property
108        def human_text(self):
109            """
110            If `True` the human readable equation expression will be
111            output in text interactive environments. Default = `False`.
112            """
113            return self.human_text
114
115        @property
116        def solve_to_list(self):
117            """
118            If `True` the results of a call to `solve(...)` will return a
119            Python `list` rather than a Sympy `FiniteSet`. This recovers
120            behavior for versions before 0.11.0.
121
122            Note: setting this `True` means that expressions within the
123            returned solutions will not be pretty-printed in Jupyter and
124            IPython.
125            """
126            return self.solve_to_list
algwsym_config.output() 
94        def __init__(self):
95            """This holds settings that impact output.
96            """
97            pass

This holds settings that impact output.

show_code = False

If True code versions of the equation expression will be output in interactive environments. Default = False.

human_text = True

If True the human readable equation expression will be output in text interactive environments. Default = False.

solve_to_list = False

If True the results of a call to solve(...) will return a Python list rather than a Sympy FiniteSet. This recovers behavior for versions before 0.11.0.

Note: setting this True means that expressions within the returned solutions will not be pretty-printed in Jupyter and IPython.

class algwsym_config.numerics: 
128    class numerics():
129
130        def __init__(self):
131            """This class holds settings for how numerical computation and
132            inputs are handled.
133            """
134            pass
135
136        def integers_as_exact(self):
137            """**This is a flag for informational purposes and interface
138            consistency. Changing the value will not change the behavior.**
139
140            To change the behavior call:
141            * `unset_integers_as_exact()` to turn this feature off.
142            * `set_integers_as_exact()` to turn this feature on (on by
143            default).
144
145            If set to `True` (the default) and if running in an
146            IPython/Jupyter environment any number input without a decimal
147            will be interpreted as a sympy integer. Thus, fractions and
148            related expressions will not evalute to floating point numbers,
149            but be maintained as exact expressions (e.g. 2/3 -> 2/3 not the
150            float 0.6666...).
151            """
152            return self.integers_as_exact
algwsym_config.numerics() 
130        def __init__(self):
131            """This class holds settings for how numerical computation and
132            inputs are handled.
133            """
134            pass

This class holds settings for how numerical computation and inputs are handled.

def integers_as_exact(self): 
136        def integers_as_exact(self):
137            """**This is a flag for informational purposes and interface
138            consistency. Changing the value will not change the behavior.**
139
140            To change the behavior call:
141            * `unset_integers_as_exact()` to turn this feature off.
142            * `set_integers_as_exact()` to turn this feature on (on by
143            default).
144
145            If set to `True` (the default) and if running in an
146            IPython/Jupyter environment any number input without a decimal
147            will be interpreted as a sympy integer. Thus, fractions and
148            related expressions will not evalute to floating point numbers,
149            but be maintained as exact expressions (e.g. 2/3 -> 2/3 not the
150            float 0.6666...).
151            """
152            return self.integers_as_exact

This is a flag for informational purposes and interface consistency. Changing the value will not change the behavior.

To change the behavior call:

  • unset_integers_as_exact() to turn this feature off.
  • set_integers_as_exact() to turn this feature on (on by default).

If set to True (the default) and if running in an IPython/Jupyter environment any number input without a decimal will be interpreted as a sympy integer. Thus, fractions and related expressions will not evalute to floating point numbers, but be maintained as exact expressions (e.g. 2/3 -> 2/3 not the float 0.6666...).

def set_integers_as_exact(): 
211def set_integers_as_exact():
212    """This operation uses `sympy.interactive.session.int_to_Integer`, which
213    causes any number input without a decimal to be interpreted as a sympy
214    integer, to pre-parse input cells. It also sets the flag
215    `algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = True` This is the default
216    mode of algebra_with_sympy. To turn this off call
217    `unset_integers_as_exact()`.
218    """
219    from IPython import get_ipython
220    if get_ipython():
221        get_ipython().input_transformers_post.append(integers_as_exact)
222        algwsym_config = get_ipython().user_ns.get("algwsym_config", False)
223        if algwsym_config:
224            algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = True
225        else:
226            raise ValueError("The algwsym_config object does not exist.")
227    return

This operation uses sympy.interactive.session.int_to_Integer, which causes any number input without a decimal to be interpreted as a sympy integer, to pre-parse input cells. It also sets the flag algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = True This is the default mode of algebra_with_sympy. To turn this off call unset_integers_as_exact().

def unset_integers_as_exact(): 
229def unset_integers_as_exact():
230    """This operation disables forcing of numbers input without
231    decimals being interpreted as sympy integers. Numbers input without a
232    decimal may be interpreted as floating point if they are part of an
233    expression that undergoes python evaluation (e.g. 2/3 -> 0.6666...). It
234    also sets the flag `algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = False`.
235    Call `set_integers_as_exact()` to avoid this conversion of rational
236    fractions and related expressions to floating point. Algebra_with_sympy
237    starts with `set_integers_as_exact()` enabled (
238    `algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = True`).
239    """
240    from IPython import get_ipython
241    if get_ipython():
242        pre = get_ipython().input_transformers_post
243        # The below looks excessively complicated, but more reliably finds the
244        # transformer to remove across varying IPython environments.
245        for k in pre:
246            if "integers_as_exact" in k.__name__:
247                pre.remove(k)
248        algwsym_config = get_ipython().user_ns.get("algwsym_config", False)
249        if algwsym_config:
250            algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = False
251        else:
252            raise ValueError("The algwsym_config object does not exist.")
253
254    return

This operation disables forcing of numbers input without decimals being interpreted as sympy integers. Numbers input without a decimal may be interpreted as floating point if they are part of an expression that undergoes python evaluation (e.g. 2/3 -> 0.6666...). It also sets the flag algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = False. Call set_integers_as_exact() to avoid this conversion of rational fractions and related expressions to floating point. Algebra_with_sympy starts with set_integers_as_exact() enabled ( algwsym_config.numerics.integers_as_exact = True).

class Equation(sympy.core.basic.Basic, sympy.core.evalf.EvalfMixin): 
256class Equation(Basic, EvalfMixin):
257    """
258    This class defines an equation with a left-hand-side (tlhs) and a right-
259    hand-side (rhs) connected by the "=" operator (e.g. `p*V = n*R*T`).
260
261    Explanation
262    ===========
263    This class defines relations that all high school and college students
264    would recognize as mathematical equations. At present only the "=" relation
265    operator is recognized.
266
267    This class is intended to allow using the mathematical tools in SymPy to
268    rearrange equations and perform algebra in a stepwise fashion. In this
269    way more people can successfully perform algebraic rearrangements without
270    stumbling over missed details such as a negative sign.
271
272    Create an equation with the call ``Equation(lhs,rhs)``, where ``lhs`` and
273    ``rhs`` are any valid Sympy expression. ``Eqn(...)`` is a synonym for
274    ``Equation(...)``.
275
276    Parameters
277    ==========
278    lhs: sympy expression, ``class Expr``.
279    rhs: sympy expression, ``class Expr``.
280    kwargs:
281
282    Examples
283    ========
284    NOTE: All the examples below are in vanilla python. You can get human
285    readable eqautions "lhs = rhs" in vanilla python by adjusting the settings
286    in `algwsym_config` (see it's documentation). Output is human readable by
287    default in IPython and Jupyter environments.
288    >>> from algebra_with_sympy import *
289    >>> a, b, c, x = var('a b c x')
290    >>> Equation(a,b/c)
291    Equation(a, b/c)
292    >>> t=Eqn(a,b/c)
293    >>> t
294    Equation(a, b/c)
295    >>> t*c
296    Equation(a*c, b)
297    >>> c*t
298    Equation(a*c, b)
299    >>> exp(t)
300    Equation(exp(a), exp(b/c))
301    >>> exp(log(t))
302    Equation(a, b/c)
303
304    Simplification and Expansion
305    >>> f = Eqn(x**2 - 1, c)
306    >>> f
307    Equation(x**2 - 1, c)
308    >>> f/(x+1)
309    Equation((x**2 - 1)/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
310    >>> (f/(x+1)).simplify()
311    Equation(x - 1, c/(x + 1))
312    >>> simplify(f/(x+1))
313    Equation(x - 1, c/(x + 1))
314    >>> (f/(x+1)).expand()
315    Equation(x**2/(x + 1) - 1/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
316    >>> expand(f/(x+1))
317    Equation(x**2/(x + 1) - 1/(x + 1), c/(x + 1))
318    >>> factor(f)
319    Equation((x - 1)*(x + 1), c)
320    >>> f.factor()
321    Equation((x - 1)*(x + 1), c)
322    >>> f2 = f+a*x**2+b*x +c
323    >>> f2
324    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c + x**2 - 1, a*x**2 + b*x + 2*c)
325    >>> collect(f2,x)
326    Equation(b*x + c + x**2*(a + 1) - 1, a*x**2 + b*x + 2*c)
327
328    Apply operation to only one side
329    >>> poly = Eqn(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
330    >>> poly.applyrhs(factor,x)
331    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, x*(c + x**2*(a + b)))
332    >>> poly.applylhs(factor)
333    Equation(x*(a*x + b + c*x), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
334    >>> poly.applylhs(collect,x)
335    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
336
337    ``.apply...`` also works with user defined python functions
338    >>> def addsquare(eqn):
339    ...     return eqn+eqn**2
340    ...
341    >>> t.apply(addsquare)
342    Equation(a**2 + a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
343    >>> t.applyrhs(addsquare)
344    Equation(a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
345    >>> t.apply(addsquare, side = 'rhs')
346    Equation(a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
347    >>> t.applylhs(addsquare)
348    Equation(a**2 + a, b/c)
349    >>> addsquare(t)
350    Equation(a**2 + a, b**2/c**2 + b/c)
351
352    Inaddition to ``.apply...`` there is also the less general ``.do``,
353    ``.dolhs``, ``.dorhs``, which only works for operations defined on the
354    ``Expr`` class (e.g.``.collect(), .factor(), .expand()``, etc...).
355    >>> poly.dolhs.collect(x)
356    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), a*x**3 + b*x**3 + c*x)
357    >>> poly.dorhs.collect(x)
358    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, c*x + x**3*(a + b))
359    >>> poly.do.collect(x)
360    Equation(b*x + x**2*(a + c), c*x + x**3*(a + b))
361    >>> poly.dorhs.factor()
362    Equation(a*x**2 + b*x + c*x**2, x*(a*x**2 + b*x**2 + c))
363
364    ``poly.do.exp()`` or other sympy math functions will raise an error.
365
366    Rearranging an equation (simple example made complicated as illustration)
367    >>> p, V, n, R, T = var('p V n R T')
368    >>> eq1=Eqn(p*V,n*R*T)
369    >>> eq1
370    Equation(V*p, R*T*n)
371    >>> eq2 =eq1/V
372    >>> eq2
373    Equation(p, R*T*n/V)
374    >>> eq3 = eq2/R/T
375    >>> eq3
376    Equation(p/(R*T), n/V)
377    >>> eq4 = eq3*R/p
378    >>> eq4
379    Equation(1/T, R*n/(V*p))
380    >>> 1/eq4
381    Equation(T, V*p/(R*n))
382    >>> eq5 = 1/eq4 - T
383    >>> eq5
384    Equation(0, -T + V*p/(R*n))
385
386    Substitution (#'s and units)
387    >>> L, atm, mol, K = var('L atm mol K', positive=True, real=True) # units
388    >>> eq2.subs({R:0.08206*L*atm/mol/K,T:273*K,n:1.00*mol,V:24.0*L})
389    Equation(p, 0.9334325*atm)
390    >>> eq2.subs({R:0.08206*L*atm/mol/K,T:273*K,n:1.00*mol,V:24.0*L}).evalf(4)
391    Equation(p, 0.9334*atm)
392
393    Substituting an equation into another equation:
394    >>> P, P1, P2, A1, A2, E1, E2 = symbols("P, P1, P2, A1, A2, E1, E2")
395    >>> eq1 = Eqn(P, P1 + P2)
396    >>> eq2 = Eqn(P1 / (A1 * E1), P2 / (A2 * E2))
397    >>> P1_val = (eq1 - P2).swap
398    >>> P1_val
399    Equation(P1, P - P2)
400    >>> eq2 = eq2.subs(P1_val)
401    >>> eq2
402    Equation((P - P2)/(A1*E1), P2/(A2*E2))
403    >>> P2_val = solve(eq2.subs(P1_val), P2).args[0]
404    >>> P2_val
405    Equation(P2, A2*E2*P/(A1*E1 + A2*E2))
406
407    Combining equations (Math with equations: lhs with lhs and rhs with rhs)
408    >>> q = Eqn(a*c, b/c**2)
409    >>> q
410    Equation(a*c, b/c**2)
411    >>> t
412    Equation(a, b/c)
413    >>> q+t
414    Equation(a*c + a, b/c + b/c**2)
415    >>> q/t
416    Equation(c, 1/c)
417    >>> t**q
418    Equation(a**(a*c), (b/c)**(b/c**2))
419
420    Utility operations
421    >>> t.reversed
422    Equation(b/c, a)
423    >>> t.swap
424    Equation(b/c, a)
425    >>> t.lhs
426    a
427    >>> t.rhs
428    b/c
429    >>> t.as_Boolean()
430    Eq(a, b/c)
431
432    `.check()` convenience method for `.as_Boolean().simplify()`
433    >>> from sympy import I, pi
434    >>> Equation(pi*(I+2), pi*I+2*pi).check()
435    True
436    >>> Eqn(a,a+1).check()
437    False
438
439    Differentiation
440    Differentiation is applied to both sides if the wrt variable appears on
441    both sides.
442    >>> q=Eqn(a*c, b/c**2)
443    >>> q
444    Equation(a*c, b/c**2)
445    >>> diff(q,b)
446    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b), c**(-2))
447    >>> diff(q,c)
448    Equation(a, -2*b/c**3)
449    >>> diff(log(q),b)
450    Equation(Derivative(log(a*c), b), 1/b)
451    >>> diff(q,c,2)
452    Equation(Derivative(a, c), 6*b/c**4)
453
454    If you specify multiple differentiation all at once the assumption
455    is order of differentiation matters and the lhs will not be
456    evaluated.
457    >>> diff(q,c,b)
458    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b, c), -2/c**3)
459
460    To overcome this specify the order of operations.
461    >>> diff(diff(q,c),b)
462    Equation(Derivative(a, b), -2/c**3)
463
464    But the reverse order returns an unevaulated lhs (a may depend on b).
465    >>> diff(diff(q,b),c)
466    Equation(Derivative(a*c, b, c), -2/c**3)
467
468    Integration can only be performed on one side at a time.
469    >>> q=Eqn(a*c,b/c)
470    >>> integrate(q,b,side='rhs')
471    b**2/(2*c)
472    >>> integrate(q,b,side='lhs')
